column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=5. Discussion
#Text=The teachers explained how difficult it is to integrate careers in science education and needed novel educational methods to overcome this challenge .
#Text=Thus , their goals and interests ( cf. ) and their need for change led them to co-designing an educational innovation .

#Text=They wanted to involve the researcher and a real professional in designing the instruction combining science knowledge with the career of a dentist and her explanations about the chemistry issues with teeth .
#Text=It was important for them to include this information in their local curriculum as proposed in previous research .
#Text=The teachers experienced a high sense of ownership and agency towards the instruction , even though they were not involved in all phases of the co-design process .
#Text=The results of teachers ’ high ownership and agency aligns with the students ’ perception of a successfully implemented co-designed career-related instruction .

#Text=The teachers highlighted the visual and informative appearance of the co-designed scenario and agreed that the virtual and personal contact with the dentist through video engaged students in following science inquiries .
#Text=Thus , the design and other ideas of the co-designers were supported .
#Text=Retrospective interviews revealed that they have continued to use and develop the scenario further .
#Text=In addition , they have shared it and discussed it with their colleagues .
#Text=This is a sign of feeling ownership as Pierce et al. argues .

#Text=When teachers are free to implement the co-designed scenario and the rest of the learning unit in their own way , it promotes their autonomy and further experiences of agency , which is particularly important when the teachers are used to high autonomy in their work .
#Text=After all , the results of the co-design process show that the teachers participated in all the phases except creating videos for the scenario and career-related activities .
#Text=However , the teachers need the freedom to change everything in the scenario and learning unit and in this case , they used this possibility a few times when they felt it was necessary .
#Text=The teachers perceived that it was easy to implement the scenario and it was successful .

#Text=Nevertheless , in such a co-design process teacher can lose some aspects , for example , feelings of control and autonomy , but gain others such as a professional ’s viewpoint and new knowledge .
#Text=In the end , the teachers appreciated that the learning unit was relevant and interesting for the students , but they were also interested in the students ’ perceptions .
#Text=The results reveal that the students found that the scenario starting the instruction was relevant for them personally and for society .
#Text=Their perceived high vocational relevance , particularly with vocational knowledge , suggests that it is possible for this kind of instruction to correct possibly existing career stereotypes .
#Text=According to the teachers and students , it seems that the problem assigned to the students personally by the dentist had an impact on students ’ interest in the following learning activities .
#Text=Earlier studies confirm that these kinds of real-world connections and student-scientist partnership are relevant and increase students ’ interest in science .
#Text=The results and previous research reveal it is not always easy or possible to create and implement this kind of authentic environment .
#Text=However , the artificially created interaction between students and professional in the designed instruction helps with the problem of resources and access to experts .
#Text=Even though the career of a dentist probably was familiar to the students before , the students perceived that they learned more about the skills and responsibilities needed in the career .
#Text=Thus , career-related instruction gives students new knowledge , not only about scientific topics , but also about careers and needed working life skills and responsibilities in a career .
#Text=All these raise students ’ career awareness and gives them accurate perceptions of STEM careers , which is assumed to increase the number of students choosing STEM studies and careers .
#Text=Considering that generally Finnish secondary school students are not that interested in science studies or science-related careers , their future career aspirations were moderate .
#Text=The students ’ interest in the scenario was high and it might raise their interest towards learning science .
#Text=As said , teachers , but also students , appreciated the scenario ’s attributes and appearance .
#Text=Something new and different always arouses interest .

#Text=Videos , connection with a professional , freedom to choose and create inquiries , and using creativity in reporting results makes science learning relevant and interesting for the students and involves them in scientific processes and decision making .

#Text=Without the career introduction and interaction with the professional , students might learn the same scientific knowledge and skills but lose connections and understanding how and why their knowledge and skills are relevant outside the school context .
